body_html:
F5 and reload does not seem to be very smooth though - probably a caching
issue where flushed data appears (with reloading) only after some time.

Can you give some pointers where to start? i might look into this one over
the weekend.

On Monday, 3 October 2016, Daniel W Mane notifications@github.com wrote:

TensorBoard does store many images per tag, but as you point out the UI
only surfaces the most recent one.

This could be improved by adding some UI for loading older images in the
sequence - maybe a slider on the left that changes which image gets loaded
by each image-loader, e.g. if the slider is set to the far left it loads
the earliest image, if it is set to far right it loads the latest image.

I don't think the TensorBoard team will prioritize this right now, but we
would gladly advise on a pull request if you (or anyone else) wants to add
this feature.

Also, you can use the reload icon in the top-left rather than F5.

—
You are receiving this because you authored the thread.
Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
#4721 (comment),
or mute the thread

.

body:
F5 and reload does not seem to be very smooth though - probably a caching
issue where flushed data appears (with reloading) only after some time.

Can you give some pointers where to start? i might look into this one over
the weekend.

On Monday, 3 October 2016, Daniel W Mane notifications@github.com wrote:

> TensorBoard does store many images per tag, but as you point out the UI
> only surfaces the most recent one.
> 
> This could be improved by adding some UI for loading older images in the
> sequence - maybe a slider on the left that changes which image gets loaded
> by each image-loader, e.g. if the slider is set to the far left it loads
> the earliest image, if it is set to far right it loads the latest image.
> 
> I don't think the TensorBoard team will prioritize this right now, but we
> would gladly advise on a pull request if you (or anyone else) wants to add
> this feature.
> 
> Also, you can use the reload icon in the top-left rather than F5.
> 
> —
